I just read some youtube comments, and I'm impressed how people can misunderstand physics. Please, can someone make video about what scientific theory is, and how it is different from absolute truth, and that any and all scientific theories have limits. Like Newtonian physics works on human-like scales, relativity is great in explaining cosmology, but not really applicable to particle physics, quantum mechanics has to incorporate relativity to explain some aspects or it's domain. Physics doesn't try to explain anything. It doesn't look for perfect explanation how everything work. We just trying to make good enough models. Difference between science and religion, that every scientists know he is wrong and his theory even proven to be true in some instance would be replaced or improved at some point.

I always thought they put off Physics due to the difficulty to teach conventional a level physics in a Crash Course format. I thought that is also why they did Astronomy instead. Once Hank announced Physics would be taught in a post a few weeks back, I thought maybe they were going to find a way to teach physics in lay person terms, like documentaries but in more detail ... General ideas in particle physics, relativity, physical chemistry and physics applications in real life etc... But it seems they really are going down the route of teaching the traditional physics course which is mainly maths. I am skeptical the crash course format is suited for this type of learning. Especially when there are other YouTube channel so which go into the nitty gritty more suitably... Just can't imagine thought cafe animating a course based mainly on calculations on a white nor are. But we'll wait and see how things turn out.
